Detailed Description

Kinematics, dynamics, and other model functions of the Barrett Arm. The term "Barrett Arm" refers to the Whole Arm Manipulator without the wrist attached (First four links only).

The BarrettArmModel class provides functions related to the modelling of the manipulator. Specifically, generic functions are provided for:

  • Forward and inverse kinematics
  • Dynamics
  • Management of manipulator configurations
  • Jacobian functions
  • Mechnical limits (e.g., joint limits)

Example Program: 

//======================================================================== 
// Project: 
// ---------------------------------------------------------------------- 
// Package: 
// Authors: 
// Start Date: Wed Apr 18 12:43:27 GMT 2001
// ----------------------------------------------------------------------  
// File: BarrettArmModel.t.cpp
// Example program for the class BarrettArmModel.
//========================================================================  
 

// ----- Standard Libaries -----
#include <iostream.h>

// ----- QRTS Libraries -----

// ----- Project Includes -----
#include "BarrettArmModel.hpp"

 
 
//======================================================================== 
// main
//========================================================================  
 
int main()
{
  return 0;
}

VectorBase * allocateJointVector ( ) [virtual]
 

Allocates a new vector of type Vector<numJoints>. The vector is allocated with "new" and needs to be freed with "delete".

Returns:
A pointer to the allocated vector.

Reimplemented from ManipulatorModel.

MatrixBase * allocateMatrixForJacobian ( ) [virtual]
 

Allocates a new matrix of type Matrix<6, numJoints>. This matrix fits exactly the Jacobian matrix. The matrix is allocated with "new" and needs to be freed with "delete".

Note that this function only allocates an empty matrix of the correct size, the jacobian is not initialized (use the functions jacobian() and inverseJacobianTranspose() for this purpose).

Returns:
A pointer to the allocated matrix.

Reimplemented from ManipulatorModel.

MatrixBase * allocateMatrixForInverseJacobian ( ) [virtual]
 

Allocates a new matrix of type Matrix<numJoints, 6>. This matrix fits exactly the inverse or transpose Jacobian matrix. The matrix is allocated with "new" and needs to be freed with "delete".

Note that this function only allocates an empty matrix of the correct size, the jacobian is not initialized (use the functions jacobianInverse() and jacobianTranspose() for this purpose).

Returns:
A pointer to the allocated matrix.

Reimplemented from ManipulatorModel.

int getNumJoints ( ) const [virtual]
 

Determines the number of joints of the manipulator.

Returns:
The number of joints.

Reimplemented from ManipulatorModel.

int getNumConfigurations ( ) const [virtual]
 

Determines the number of configurations that the manipulator has. This value is identical to the number of solutions of the inverse kinematics for a specific end-effector position (Considering a non-redundant robot).

Returns:
The number of configurations.

Reimplemented from ManipulatorModel.

const char * getConfigurationName ( int configuration ) const [virtual]
 

Returns the name for the configuration (e.g., "wrist up", "wrist down", etc.).

Parameters:
configuration   Index of the configuration.

Reimplemented from ManipulatorModel.

virtual bool isForwardKinematicsImplemented ( ) const [virtual]
 

Determines if the function forwardKinematics() is implemented. This class always returns false, because in the class ManipulatorModel, no function is implemented. A derived class must return true if the function is implemented.

Returns:
true: This function is implemented.
false: The function is not implemented.

Example: 

     Puma robot;
     ManipulatorModel *model = robot.getManipulatorModel();
    
     if (model->isForwardKinematicsImplemented())
     {
       Vector<6> jointPosition;
       robot.getCurrentJointPosition(jointPosition);
    
       cout << "End-Effector T6 Transform: " << endl
            << forwardKinematics(jointPosition) << endl;
     }
     else
     {
       cout << "Forward kinematics is not implemented!" << endl;
     }

Reimplemented from ManipulatorModel.

virtual bool isInverseKinematicsImplemented ( ) const [virtual]
 

Determines if the function inverseKinematics() is implemented. This class always returns false, because in the class ManipulatorModel, no function is implemented. A derived class must return true if the function is implemented.

Returns:
true: This function is implemented.
false: The function is not implemented.

Reimplemented from ManipulatorModel.

bool isJacobianImplemented ( ) const [virtual]
 

The jacobian functions are implemented.

Reimplemented from ManipulatorModel.

bool isInverseJacobianImplemented ( ) const [virtual]
 

The inverse jacobian functions are implemented.

Returns:
true.

Reimplemented from ManipulatorModel.

bool isDynamicsImplemented ( ) const [virtual]
 

The dynamics functions are currently not implemented. for the WAM.

Returns:
false.

Reimplemented from ManipulatorModel.

Transform forwardKinematics ( const VectorBase<>& jointPosition,
int & configuration ) [virtual]
 

Performs the forward kinematics calculation (Calculates the end-effector transform and configuration from the joint position).

Parameters:
jointPosition   A vector containing the position of each joint in degrees (revolute joint)/meters (prismatic joint).
configuration   This variable is set to the resulting configuration of the manipulator. Is it possible to omit this parameter.
Returns:
The corresponding 4x4 homogenous transformation calculated using the forward kinematics.

Reimplemented from ManipulatorModel.

bool inverseKinematics ( const Transform & endEffectorTransform,
int configuration,
VectorBase<>& jointPosition,
double epsilon = 0.1 ) [virtual]
 

Performs the inverse kinmatics calculation (Calculates the joint position from the end-effector transform and configuration).

Parameters:
endEffectorTransform   The end-effector position and orientation
configuration   The end-effector configuration.
epsilon   A measure of how close the user wants to get to a singularity.
jointPosition   The calculated joint position vector.
Returns:
false: if the robot is in near to a singularpoint (as much as epsilon)
true: No singularity detected.

Reimplemented from ManipulatorModel.

void jacobian ( const VectorBase<>& jointPosition,
MatrixBase<>& jacobian ) [virtual]
 

Calculates the manipulator Jacobian from given the joint position.

Parameters:
jointPosition   The current position of the manipulator.
jacobian   The corresponding Jacobian matrix.

Reimplemented from ManipulatorModel.

MatrixBase<>& jacobianTranspose ) [virtual]

Parameters:

void inverseJacobian ( const VectorBase<>& jointPosition,
MatrixBase<>& inverseJacobian ) [virtual]
 

Calculates the inverse or the corresponding pseudoinverse of the Jacobian matrix from the given joint position.

Parameters:
jointPosition   The current position of the manipulator.
inverseJacobian   The corresponding inverse Jacobian matrix.
